articles.author: Mr. Z
articles.description:
The PetShop project: First day on Ethereum


I'm planning to build a simple web3 pet shop application from scratch. Every day I'll try to enhance

articles.author: Luke Cartwright
articles.description:
If you are anything like me, you have a few small projects that you are hosting on Herkoku. Read on to learn more about some of the changes that will likely affect you.
Heroku is a Platform As A Service (PAAS) "based on a managed container system, with integrated data services and a powerful ecosystem, for deploying and running modern apps" heroku.com.
This means that, with a small amount of config, you can get your web app live and available to the world without setting up servers. Heroku offers, what they call, Dynos. These are used to run your code and a small servers to run your Web apps on.
Currently Heroku offers a generous free tier so that developers can get their web apps up and running quickly and for free. 
The only real downsides are not enabling a custom domain and slower coldâ€¦
articles.title: Heroku is removing the free tier

articles.author: Frank Rosner
articles.description:
Introduction


When the pandemic started, we set ourselves a learning goal: develop a backend using only serverless technologies. Initially, we set out to make this happen using technologies we were already familiar with, AWS Lambda and Java. But to spice things up, we decided to add some new technologies to the mix â€” GraalVM to eliminate the JVM Lambda cold start problem, and DataStax Astra DB as our serverless DBaaS.
So, we spent a couple of hours per week on building a serverless order processing API using Astra DB and AWS. Due to the pandemic, you could call it a distributed â€œhackathonâ€ of sorts, in which we had three main challenges:
Access Astra DB from within AWS Lambda
Write automatic tests for our Astra DB client
Set up the Lambda function to use the GraalVM native image runtime
Iâ€¦
articles.title: How We Built a Serverless Backend Using GraalVM, AWS Lambda and Astra DB (Part 1)

articles.author: Thomas Hansen
articles.description:
Creating an HTTP web API endpoint by adding hardcoded SQL directly into your endpoint's method is the equivalent of cursing in church. I have worked with software developers who would become physically violent if I told them to do such a thing. However, let's stop and ask ourselves why this apparently is such a bad thing. I really can't see the problem here. Hence, put your SQL directly into your HTTP endpoint code.
There are tons of arguments against it, but once you really think about these, few of them makes much sense for most projects today. Once you've started implementing your project, it's highly unlikely you'll ever want to change database implementation from MySQL to PostgreSQL. So the argument of being able to exchange your database implementation is basically mute.
Using an ORMâ€¦
articles.title: Put your SQL directly into your HTTP endpoint code

articles.author: Michelle Mannering
articles.description:
Remember I talked about the pillars of DevOps, and what DevOps actually is?
The pillars of DevOps. What is a DevOps engineer?
Michelle Mannering ãƒ» Sep 27 '21 ãƒ» 4 min read
#devops
        #devrel
        #discuss
      
Well, I wanted to dive a little deeper into the importance of collaboration and why it is a pillar of DevOps.
A lot of people hear the word "DevOps" and they immediately think CI/CD. All thoughts center on coding and nothing else. This isn't everyone obviously, but many people believe DevOps is a tool, a platform to help get code deployed out into the world. This is part of it but not the only part. DevOps is as much a cultural change, a mindset, and practices as it is about the tools and products used.

Image: Antonio Janeski via Unsplash 
Collaborating and working togetherâ€¦
articles.title: The importance of collaboration, a DevOps pillar

articles.author: Vakindu Philliam
articles.description:
Overview of My Submission


Fin PEN is an AI powered fintech app used to analyze customer invoice receipt images in realtime, allowing business owners to better understand client spending habits.
The app receives customer invoice receipt images in realtime, captures the receipt's data, and analyses the captured results to better understand customer spending habits.
Fin PEN's system architecture is split into 3 core units, image, analysis and storage. 
The app uses Redis' queuing system to receive, track and process requests and RedisJSON to store the analyzed data.

articles.author: Chris Bongers
articles.description:
We already created a basic extension that made all the websites we visit pink, but what if we want that action to only happen when we click a button inside our popup extensions?
Well, in this article, we'll learn just that, and even better, we base the color of our local storage that we implemented in a previous article.
If you wish to follow this article, use this GitHub branch as your starting point.
What we want to achieve today is that by clicking a button inside our popup extension, the color of the active tab changes.

We'll first need to add some new permissions to our manifest.json file.
{
  "permissions": ["alarms", "notifications", "storage", "activeTab", "scripting"],
}

The new ones are activeTab and scripting.
activeTab allows us to modify and retrieve the active tab
scriptingâ€¦
articles.title: Browser extensions - Popup page modifications

articles.author: Renan Franca
articles.description:
After I run the JHipster generator  for the first time I realized that the back end implemented with spring boot doesn't use Lombok. So I decided to customize the generated code to use lombok than I realized it wasn't the best way to use JHipster.
When I realized how awesome JHipster was I thought that I should change the generated code to be like the one I used to type manually. So I saw the opportunity to create my own blueprint with the following custom annotations:
Add Lombok - @lombok
Hide comment - @noCodeComment
Change the database scheme - @schema
Add Id GeneratedValue to entity - @generatedValue(identity)
Define column database name - @column(ds_field) 
Use unsupported types - @newFieldTypeImport(import_class_package_type) and @newFieldType(type)
I opened source my blueprint whichâ€¦
articles.title: JHipster does not use lombok. Why?

articles.author: Navendu Pottekkat
articles.description:
As your APIs scale, the need for making them reliable and robust increases.
This article discusses the best practices for building reliable APIs by introducing a special kind of reverse proxies called API gateways.
We will look into:
 Problems with traditional API designs
 What API gateways are
 How API gateways improve APIs and
 Patterns and examples using API gateways
But first, what are "reliable" APIs?
As a service provider, you might have service-level agreements (SLAs) with your customers, usually quoted in uptime---the amount of time the service is guaranteed to be online and operational.
Uptime is a myopic view of reliability. To understand what it means to be reliable, you have to look at the factors that affect uptime. Once you understand these factors, you will be in a better poâ€¦
articles.title: Best Practices for Building Reliable APIs

articles.author: Faisal Nizam
articles.description:
Often when we are talking about container and docker images the things that comes to mind in terms to deployment is 
Kubernetes
ECS or Fargate 
Docker Swarm or Docker Daemon 
Although these are the most commonly used technologies for deployments but for a small set of stateless applications this is comes over with a lot of management overheard. 
At this point AWS has given the leverage to deploy and build container images on Lambda and run as any simple application. 
Lets look into building and deploying a DOCKER application using serverless. 
Pre-Req: 
Docker Daemon
Serverless utility 
ECR and AWS Login Details 
Install Serverless Utility
npm install -g serverless

Once installed lets create a structure using serverless utility for our node application 
Create a Dockerfile to run your appâ€¦
articles.title: Serverless and Containers

articles.author: Chris Hermansen
articles.description:
How I analyze my music directory with Groovy
Chris Hermansen
Fri, 08/26/2022 - 03:00

    
1 reader likes this
1 reader likes this
Lately, Iâ€™ve been looking at how Groovy streamlines the slight clunkiness of Java. In this article, I begin a short series to demonstrate Groovy scripting by creating a tool to analyze my music directory.
In this article, I demonstrate how the groovy.File class extends and streamlines java.File and simplifies its use. This provides a framework for looking at the contents of a music folder to ensure that expected content (for example, a cover.jpg file) is in place. I use the JAudiotagger library to analyze the tags of any music files.
Install Java and Groovy
Groovy is based on Java and requires a Java installation. Both a recent and decent version of Java and Grâ€¦
articles.title: How I analyze my music directory with Groovy

articles.author: Jesse White
articles.description:
My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO
Jesse White
Fri, 08/26/2022 - 03:00

    
1 reader likes this
1 reader likes this
When people ask me what I love most about open source, my answer is simple: It's the openness. With open source, the work that community developers and contributors do is in the public domain for all to see and benefit from. I couldn't love that philosophy more.
How many people can say that about the fruits of their labor? How many, perhaps 50 years from now, can look back and say, "Check out the code I wrote that day that hundreds/thousands/tens of thousands benefited from." I find that infinitely more exciting than working on software that's hidden from most of the world.
I'm fortunate that my job puts me in the middle of an interesting area where open â€¦
articles.title: My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO

articles.author: AmyJune Hineline
articles.description:
Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories
AmyJune Hineline
Thu, 08/25/2022 - 08:01

    
4 readers like this
4 readers like this
On August 25, 1991, Linux 0.01 was announced. All of us have a story to tell about Linux. I told my story a couple of months ago, but for those who weren't here: My first exposure to Linux was when my grassroots hospice organization moved from paper to digital charting. We didn't have the funding to get something proprietary, but the IT department had Linux set up on our old machine, and we used the GNOME desktop and OpenOffice to start our journey in creating digital assets.
I recently asked some Opensource.com authors this simple question:
What was your first Linux experience?
From VAX to Linux
For my junior year of high school, I was shipped off tâ€¦
articles.title: Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories

articles.author: Pravein Govindan Kannan
articles.description:
Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud
Pravein Govindâ€¦
Thu, 08/25/2022 - 03:00

    
Register or Login to like
Register or Login to like
Observability is the ability to know and interpret the current state of a deployment, and a way to know when something is amiss. With cloud deployments of applications as microservices on Kubernetes and OpenShift growing, observability is getting a lot of attention. Many applications come with strict guarantees, such as service level agreements (SLA) for downtimes, latency, and throughput, so network-level observability is a highly imperative feature. Network-level observability is provided by several orchestrators, either natively or by using plugins and operators.
Recently, eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) emerged as a popular option toâ€¦
articles.title: Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud

articles.author: Peter Czanik
articles.description:
7 sudo myths debunked
Peter Czanik
Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00

    
2 readers like this
2 readers like this
Whether attending conferences or reading blogs, I often hear several misconceptions about sudo. Most of these misconceptions focus on security, flexibility, and central management. In this article, I will debunk some of these myths.
Many misconceptions likely arise because users know only the basic functionality of sudo. The sudoers file, by default, has only two rules: The root user, and members of the administrative wheel group, can do practically anything using sudo. There are barely any limits, and optional features are not enabled at all. Even this setup is better than sharing the root password, as you can usually follow who did what on your systems using the logs. However, learninâ€¦
articles.title: 7 sudo myths debunked

Raigor Jiang
Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00

    
1 reader likes this
1 reader likes this
Apache ShardingSphere 5.0.0-Beta version with DistSQL made the project even more beloved by developers and ops teams for its advantages, such as dynamic effects, no restart, and elegant syntax close to standard SQL. With upgrades to 5.0.0 and 5.1.0, the ShardingSphere community has once again added abundant syntax to DistSQL, bringing more practical features.
In this article, the community co-authors will share the latest functions of DistSQL from the perspective of cluster governance.
ShardingSphere clusters
In a typical cluster composed of ShardingSphere-Proxy, there are multiple compute nodes and storage nodes, as shown in the figure below.
  


     â€¦
articles.title: Your guide to DistSQL's cluster governance capability

articles.description:
How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration
David Both
Tue, 08/23/2022 - 03:00

    
3 readers like this
3 readers like this
NetworkManager was introduced in 2004 to make network configuration more flexible and dynamic. The old SystemV startup shell scripts, of which the interface configuration files were a part, were incapable of handling WiFi, wired, VPNs, broadband modems, and moreâ€”or at least incapable of doing it quickly or efficiently.
In a series of articles, I've written about why I'm a fan of NetworkManager and how I've used it. In part 1, I looked at what NetworkManager does and some of the tools it provides for viewing network connections and devices. In that article, I mentioned that NetworkManager does not need interface configuration files for most hosts. Howeâ€¦
articles.title: How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration

articles.author: Josh Salomon
articles.description:
Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source
Josh Salomon
Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00

    
6 readers like this
6 readers like this
Many developers struggle with work-life balance. They are overloaded with regular tasks and frequently called upon to solve urgent customer issues. Yet many developers, like me, have ideas they want to promote if only they had time to do so. Sometimes these pet ideas do not make it through the product management feature-selection process. Other times, a developer does not have time to complete the solution end-to-end on their own, yet they know if it could somehow be implemented, the project would benefit.
This is where mentoring comes in. Mentorship has many benefits: It helps the mentee's personal development, and it can improve the mentor's self-confidence anâ€¦
articles.title: Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source

articles.description:
My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux
Alan Formy-Duval
Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00

    
3 readers like this
3 readers like this
New on the GNOME desktop is their terminal emulator application simply named Console. It seems aimed at providing a no-nonsense, stable command-line environment for Linux users.
Introducing GNOME Console for Linux
  


      
   
Image by: 
â€‹(Alan Formy-Duval, CC BY-SA 4.0)
â€‹


  
The GNOME Console isn't as feature-rich as a lot of other terminals, including the previous GNOME terminal, but I like it and have been using it regularly for the past few months. I enjoy the simplicity of it. I waste time in other terminal emulators configuring fonts, colors, and profiles.
Console does have some options and nice integration with the GNOME desktop. I'll start with tâ€¦
articles.title: My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux

articles.author: AmyJune Hineline
articles.description:
What's your favorite screenshot tool on Linux?
AmyJune Hineline
Sat, 08/20/2022 - 03:00

    
4 readers like this
4 readers like this
As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words, and while that's not always the case with terminal commands and code, it still holds true for the graphical desktop. Screenshots capture precisely what's on your screen. I love taking them to have a record of who attends meetings, so I don't have to write it down at the moment. Or to capture a bug when doing UI testing. We all take them for different reasons, though, and there are more ways to take a screenshot than you might at first think.
I started thinking about screenshots after Jim Hall wrote an article listing GNOME screenshots, GIMP, and Firefox as the ways he often takes screenshots. And yet tâ€¦
articles.title: What's your favorite screenshot tool on Linux?

LG has announced a new 45-inch ultrawide OLED gaming monitor with a refresh rate of 240Hz. The company is calling the UltraGear 45GR95QE its â€œfirst curved OLED display with a 240Hz refresh rate,â€ which is notable at a time when most OLED displays (including those with flat panels) are still capped at 120Hz. The company is yet to announce pricing or a release date for the monitor, but plans to show it off at IFA in Berlin next month.
Having a higher refresh rate means a display appears smoother and less juddery, and video games feel more responsive to play â€” especially when combined with OLEDâ€™s near-instantaneous response times. While countries like Russia and China have been making headlines for years with their disinformation and propaganda campaigns on platforms like Twitter and Facebook, it turns out that the US and other Western countries have been playing the same game. A recent report (pdf) from social network analysis firm Graphika and the Stanford Internet Observatory has uncovered a series of operations, some covert and some less so, that aimed to â€œpromote pro-Western narrativesâ€ in countries like Russia, China, Afghanistan, and Iran (via Gizmodo).

The patent application covers several possible variants of a device that combines a camera, an infrared light emitter, and a â€œlight folding elementâ€ that can redirect the IR light. articles.description:
What does it do?

Life Goals OS is part guide part product. It breaks down what goal-setting is about and how it works. It guides you through a simple workflow to brainstorm, define, progress, review and accomplish your goals. Itâ€™s set up as an iterative system to get better at getting better. 

Whatâ€™s included?

- Resources and guides on goal-setting based on work of various authors such as Stephen Covey, Bill Burnett & Dave Evans, Naval Ravikant and Chris Bailey
- A clean dashboard for your goals which you can orient your existing goal management systems around
- Checklists and templates that guide you through the processes of setting and checking in with your goals.

Why did I make it?

It was the scratch-your-own-itch-factor. Well, more than just my own itch. Whenever I ask my team and friends what they struggle with the most it's unanimously goal setting. Wat goals should I set? How do I define good goals? How do I stay on track? As COO and Product Manager at our 40-employee business I landed on OKRs as the goal-setting framework of preference. So, After having tried and tested the system for the past years it felt like the right thing to launch as my first indie-project. 

Iâ€™ve been eager to start with independent projects for a while now. As ferocious Product Hunt follower itâ€™s incredibly exciting to be on the launching-end for the first time. Iâ€™m grateful for my colleagues and online-friends whoâ€™ve encouraged me to take this step. And, a massive shout out to the Product Hunt community for nurturing such a great launch pad.

In celebration of the launch all Product Hunters get 50% off with code: ph50 


Iâ€™m excited to see your feedback and happy to answer any questions you might have!

articles.description:
@keyframes are some of the things I use most frequently, so I wanted to build them the way I thought they should be. My goal was to create simple tools that are private, local, customizable, and easy to use, without all the annoying junk like massive ads, popups, invasive tracking, or forced social media integration.


ğŸ‘¾ CSS @Keyframe Animation Editor
A tool that gives you a timeline (like movie editing software) to easily create and preview CSS animations. 

â  Box-Shadow generator
Simply move some sliders to adjust your shadow, add multiple layers, then get the CSS.

ğŸ¨ Colors
Create & convert colors, create color palettes, view color contrast and colorblindness, create gradients, and share your palettes.

âŒ¨ï¸ Character codes
Search for and easily copy special character CSS and HTML values.

ğŸ‘‹ What makes it stand out:
â€¢ It's free - all features. 
â€¢ It's private & local - Keyframes only uses Local Storage, and there are no 3rd party trackers or ad networks. It's also open source, so you can verify.
â€¢ The UI is customizable - the theme, font, borders, and behaviors like confirmation dialogues and tooltips can be disabled.
â€¢ Created from scratch - no frontend frameworks or 3rd-party libraries let me get everything just how I wanted it.


So if you're a developer or designer who works with CSS a lot, I hope these tools can be useful and save you some time. I'll be adding more tools over the coming weeks - so keep an eye out!

I'd love to hear any questions, suggestions, ideas for other tools, criticism, or anything else you have to say!

articles.description:
@linusgeffarth) and I've been building WikiSpaces on and off last year. But what's this all about?

ğŸ¥¥ in a nutshell
WikiSpaces 3D is about enabling people to go places *virtually*, where they couldn't go otherwise (physically), by providing a collection of such places as 3d-scans, "spaces" ğŸª, explorable in VR (yes, also with vr glasses). (3D-scans made with Matterport.)
There are already some really cool spaces: from Boeing 747 cockpits to Egyptian temples or the LeBron James Arena!

ğŸ¤” but why?
Mainly, it's about providing educational value and making knowledge accessible: in the times of the COVID-19 pandemic, students are not able to visit interesting places like museums or galleries; but if said place has been 3d-scanned and shared on WikiSpaces, students can visit it virtually.
But it's really about everyone: some of the spaces allow exclusive visits to places you could normally never go to, such as a Boeing 747 cockpit (unless your friend's friend is a pilot of course, ha), or simply places far far away.

ğŸ’° really free?
Yes absolutely! Just like Wikipedia aims to share knowledge for free, WikiSpaces does too. Building WikiSpaces has been possible only because the ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º EU has provided generous funding (subsidies) for this project.
What about user-submitted content though? All spaces are shared under the CC BY 4.0 license.

ğŸ‘‰ what now?
Check out the featured spaces, or scroll down to the explore page and check out a space (or two if you'd like ğŸ˜). There are already some really cool spaces, from Boeing 747 cockpits to Egyptian temples or the LeBron James Arena!
And then I'd love it if you could spread the word, share a link, and follow me on twitter @wikispaces3d (I'll be a bit more active there soon ğŸ¤)

â“ Questions? As away! Looking forward to hearing y'all's thoughts! ğŸ™

Here's how it works
There are a couple of things going on inside that search engine, but I'll try to boil it down to simple points.

â„¹ï¸ We collect product info from ProductHunt using their API
ğŸ¦€ We crawl the internet and look for articles that mention the products from ProductHunt 
ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» We then extract appropriate keywords that are relevant to the product
ğŸ“œ We build the index out of keywords that are collected
Note: Our Index size is small, so you might get some irrelevant results. But I've been working hard to scale the index size!

Ranking
I've been experimenting with a couple of ranking ideas but one that I've found to be particularly effective is this

 ğŸ—‚ï¸ We only consider links that are organic, meaning they aren't paid for or incentivized
  â¬‡ï¸ The engine sometimes penalizes the products for some keywords, if it has too many sponsored backlinks

articles.description:
How many tech content do you read and save everyday?

For me: there's articles about DevOps, twitter thread about web dev, docs of Kubernetesâ€¦ 

I read and saved 20+ resources everyday. ğŸ§

I tried many tools for archiving resources, but none of them perfectly suit my workflow. So does others in Depths. ğŸ™ƒ

We hate having to tag resources with #Python or #WebDev then manually adding them to folders every single time. Especially when we got like  100+ tabs opening in the same moment. ğŸ¤¯

Thatâ€™s where we thought - what if thereâ€™s a solution that is:

1ï¸âƒ£ Simple
2ï¸âƒ£ Fast
3ï¸âƒ£ Automated

Thatâ€™s why we decided to make Depths.

Our goal is to help developers to archive & retrieve knowledge in the easiest way possible. To do this, Depths support:

â€¢ Auto-tagging ğŸ”–
â€¢ Full-text search ğŸ” 
â€¢ Estimated read time â³
â€¢ Import your current bookmarks â¬‡ï¸
â€¢  â€¦ and more for you to explore!

This Alpha version is the first step of our project to make a better bookmark manager for devs. Our goal is to become the best knowledge base tool for devs on the market. ğŸš€

As a small team of 4 working part-time, user feedback means the world to us. Feel free to try it and let us know what you think of it! ğŸ’›

Weâ€™ll be here for the next 24 hours to answer your questions. Also youâ€™re very welcome to come to our Discord server to chat with us! https://discord.gg/MSbqnVzB ğŸ‘‹

P.S. If you followed me before, you'll know the previous product I made on is Savvy, which is also a bookmark manager but it didn't have product-market fit. Therefore we spent months on researching and pivoted it into Depths. And I wrote a blog about the entire process :) https://desmond-hth.medium.com/n...
